name: Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin)
summary: Vitamin B2, or riboflavin, is a water-soluble vitamin that plays a critical role in energy metabolism, antioxidant defense, and cellular function.
description: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) is an essential B-complex vitamin required for the production of flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) and flavin mononucleotide (FMN), coenzymes that participate in numerous redox reactions involved in energy production, metabolism of fats, carbohydrates, and proteins, and antioxidant protection. It also supports healthy skin, eyes, and neurological function. Deficiency can cause ariboflavinosis, presenting with sore throat, angular cheilitis, glossitis, and anemia. Supplementation is sometimes used in the prevention of migraines and to support overall metabolic health.

metadata.natural_source: Milk, eggs, lean meats, green leafy vegetables, fortified cereals

primary_indications: Prevention and treatment of riboflavin deficiency (ariboflavinosis)
off_label_uses: Supportive role in eye health (e.g., keratoconus with riboflavin + UV therapy)

items: Prevention and treatment of riboflavin deficiency (ariboflavinosis)

sections.text: Riboflavin functions as a precursor for coenzymes FAD and FMN, which are essential in mitochondrial energy metabolism, electron transport, and antioxidant enzyme function.

adult.typical: Oral: 5–30 mg/day for supplementation; up to 400 mg/day in migraine prophylaxis
adult.clinical: IV: used in metabolic disorders under medical supervision

sections.pediatric: 1–3 mg/day depending on age; higher doses in deficiency states under supervision

sections.text: Improvement of deficiency symptoms typically within days to weeks; migraine prevention effects may take 1–3 months of regular use.

other: Excess intake is generally safe since riboflavin is water-soluble and excreted in urine.
High doses may cause harmless yellow-orange discoloration of urine.

items: Migraine frequency if used for prevention

sections.pregnancy: Safe at recommended dietary doses; sometimes used in prenatal supplements
sections.lactation: Safe and excreted in breast milk at low levels
sections.pediatrics: Safe at recommended dietary allowance; clinical doses for deficiency require supervision
sections.geriatrics: Safe and may help prevent age-related deficiency

sections.text: No tapering required; can discontinue without withdrawal effects.

items: Often included in multivitamins and B-complex formulations.
High-dose riboflavin (400 mg/day) is effective in some patients for migraine prevention.
Riboflavin is photosensitive; supplements should be stored away from light.
